Fort Gill [L.Z.]
Sept 16th 1874
My Dear General,
Yours of the 21st ult just received- I have just time to give you a short account of contemplated movement against the indians before the mail closes. 
General Davidson moves out on Thursday with 5 Cos of Cavalry and two of Infantry "B" and H [troops] go into Camp today near Medicine Bluff followed by C and H Tomorrow. "M" will I presume leave with the General. The expedition takes rations for a month. Woodward goes as Adjutant of the Regiment and Smither as a Adjutant General.

Buell with 4 Companies of Cavalry and two of Infantry is expected here to-day - he moves out in advance of General D. Nolan is with Buell.  General Augur arrived here a few days ago escorted by two Companies of the 9th Cavalry under Major Morrow.  Kennedy and Keyes are here, and will garrison the Post during the absence of the expedition.  Lawson [underline], Lyttle, and Morrison are at the Witchita Agency.  Nothing from Miles' Column yet.  He was reported within three days march of the Wichita Agency when I wrote you last, but it appears that was a canard.

       I have talked with Jones and everyone else about the fight, and can only learn of one indian killed at the fight.  We had none killed, but three wounded, Jones says there was too much talk.  They literally sacked Shirlays store nearly under the eyes of the troops.  The report about Viele not being able to get his men mounted when the indians first fired was incorrect.  The men all behaved admirably, Morrisons Company had the honor of firing the first-shot.
       Col Wood will come here from Richardson to command the Post during Genl. D's absence.  The indians stole all Whaleys stock last

week - 29 head in number.   Recd. letter from Moyers last mail, I fear he is not doing as well as we could wish.  Poor fellow he had had a big load to carry, and I do not wonder that he sinks under it [underline last 2 words].  Under all the circumstances I think the Regiment would be the best place for him.

   Inspector General Baird paid us a visit - leaving for Fort Richardson yesterday.  I shall take pleasure in keeping you posted, and will write when there is anything of interest.  I applied sometime a go to have my sentence suspended until after active operations were over, but have recd no answer.  Mr. N joins me in regards to yourself and Mrs. Grierson.
                                    Hastily from
                                       Nordstrom

Genl B H Grierson

Sill  Sept 10"      [1874]
My Dear General:

                              The Army moved this morning Six Companies of Cavalry and three of Infantry, the five Companies of our own garrison and "L" Company are the Cavalry.    Wycoff's, Bowens and Beach's are the companies of the 11" Infantry.

They move from here to Fort Cobb, In the meantime it is rumored the Indians have gone South to McClellans Creek, leaving the Washita entirely.  If that's the case cant see why the troops go to Cobb,  Buell [underline] get here day  before yesterday.  Has to wait here for forage, when supplied he goes to the mouth of Wauderers Creek (what used to be called Schofields Creek,) establishing a camp there to intercept the indians should they go south.  He has [underline] Six Companies of Cavalry and two of Infantry.  Nolan is with him.   There are now ten Companies of the Regiment in the Territory, B, C, H. K, L. and "M" with Davidson.   E at the Witchita Agency, D and H Garrison Sill, and A with Buell.  "I" at Richardson "G" at Griffin, Genl Augur with the Payruanter (Judd) left this morning for the W. Agency    The troops are

rationed for 30 days.  It is rumored here that if the indians are not wiped out in that time, they will return to Sill, where you will have command of the next column.  I do not know hat foundation there is for this, and merely give it to you as garrison gossip.  I have heard it mentioned several times, and there is evidently some belief in the report.  Of course you will know whether it is true or not.    25 or 30 indian scouts mostly Commanches, have been hired and are under the Command of Pratt, McKenzie with the major portion of his Regiment is camped on the Fresh

2
water Form of the Brazos.  Do not know whether he will come north or not.

    I have received no answer to my application to be released during active operations.  I am very sorry as I wanted to see some indian fighting - However I have placed myself right on the record, and leave the result with the powers that be.
                   Hastily Yours
                               Nordstrom

Headquarters Ft. Richardson
Texas.  October 7th 1869.
Bvt. Maj. Genl. B. H. Grierson
Col. 10th Cavly.
Comdg, Fort Sill, I. T.

               &c &c

General,

              Your letter of the 2d inst was handed me yesterday by Capt. Byrne 10th Cavly.
    In reply I beg leave to assure you it will afford me pleasure to Co-operate with you to the extent of the means at my disposal to prevent any further depredations in Texas, by the Indians from their Reservation.    The great difficulty I labor under is the want of Cavalry forces for Scouting purposes, the drain upon my Command at this Post for Civil Service being so great as to almost entirely absorb all my Cavalry, which when all present, is very limited in point of numbers.
    At present I have not an available

Officer, nor more than a dozen Mounted men who could possibly be spared from their Post for Scouting Service.

    As Commander of this Sub-District of the Brazos, I have the troops stationed at Ft. Griffin at my disposal for Scouting & other purposes, & from that Post I can accomplish something more than at present [2 words underline] from here.  I have discussed the situation freely with Capt. Byrne who can post you as regards the limited effective mounted force both here & at Ft. Griffin.
    Could we be notified here of the movements of the Indians when coming south of Red River in time, we might do something towards over- taking & chastising them before their return; but when we learn of their being on this side of Red river it is generally after they have committed some depredation & too late to overtake them before crossing back on their reserve where they are perfectly safe.
    The only suggestion I can now make is for me to keep scouting parties out as constantly as my limited force will warrant & for you

to make such disposition of your forces as your judgment may dictate, to keep the indians within the limits of their reservation, & if practicable, from crossing the Red River into Texas.

    I will be pleased to receive your views at all times, and will be thankful for any suggestions that will enable me more effectually to co-operate with you.
                    I am General
                    Very Respectfully,
                       Yr. Obdt. Servt
                           James Oakes
                           Col 6th Cavly &
                           Bt Brig Genl

Hd. Qrs. Ft. Richardson, Texas,
September 17th 1870
Col. B. H. Grierson
10th Cavalry,
Comdg. Ft. Sill, I. T.
Colonel,

                The bearer of this Mr. Jesse Maxey a citizen of Montague Co. Texas, visits your Post for the purpose of recovering, if possible, his two children who were carried off by indians on the 5th inst.                    I take pleasure in recommending Mr. Maxey to your most favorable consideration and beg to assure you that any assistance rendered, or favors extended by you will be duly appreciated.
    Mr. Maxey & his friend Mr. J. A. Davis, will be furnished an escort from my temporary Camp on the East Fort of the Little Wichita River  
    Trusting you may be successful in

restoring the two stolen children to their father, I am Colonel,

                          Very Respectfully,
                             Yr. Obdt Servt,
                               James Oakes
                                  Col. 6th Cavly

Fort Niagara N. Y.
Nov 4th 1884.
Gen B. H. Grierson U.S.A.
My dear General,

                           Your Circular, enclosing Bill to be presented to Congress, has reached me by todays mail, and I hasten to answer it, that pure {?} adventure I may be able to show you wherein I believe it will be to our disadvantage, and where it shows when analized that share realy benifited are those officers holding now the Commission of Col.
    If you will have noticed the feeling of Congress the one strong point shown has been that[strike] a disinclination to vote large sums of money for the Army, for any purpose, no matter how great the necessity, and one of the first things in the next Congress that will be asked in regard to any bill is how much money is this going to take if we pass it. [underline all words since "how"]  Both parties are in the most binding manner pledged to economy, and I am most fully convinced that the promises given will be fulfilled.  The bill you now present

involves in its passage an enormous appropriation, which you never can get them to make.  I know this from my conversation with the members of the Committees of both Houses last winter.  Now let me ask you why do you want to abandon that most excellent bill, instigated by you, as I found on arrival in Washington, in conversation with Mr Springer, and introduced by him?   it was one of, if not the best measure for the Army at large ever introduced, as soon as I saw it, I became satisfied it was just the thing we wanted, and I at once went to work studying the matter up and wrote the address to congress which you approved of, (but to refresh your memory I enclose a copy,) and which received the approval of over 80 percent of the Army.   I went to Washington primarily to procure an appointment for my son, and went to see how the land laid for Army legislation, and what chances there was for any bill.  As I expected  found the Committees overwhelmed with bills and letters from officers, differing in opinion as wide as the poles are apart, as one said to me we are willing to do for the officers, but "we dont believe you  [underline 4 words]

produce something, if the Army responded to the call and send in their subscriptions, but * doubt it, for they have handicapped their, well known [2 word underline] committe, by, forcing a measure upon them which helps only the Capts. and Lieutenants, they, the originators, have decided what measures are to be presented, without consultation or advise from the Army at large.  If they carry their point, the old returns are or will be set aside, those who stood the brunt of battle on scores of fields, become secondary considerations, and those benefited are those whose services have been since [underline] the War, but this is concealed under verbage.  Now Genls. if we, the Cols, Lt. Cols & Maj. will combine we can pass the Springer bill. I am willing to couple the Harmer fill with it for the benefit of the whole Army, but not jeopardize our interests If this Fort Sanders Syndicate will put that in their bill, & will [strike] would be satisfied, were I not afraid of their sincerity, as they have started off comitting us.  We have every reason to believe we can pass the Springer bill, eaven as a separate

measure, all the evidence is in, the measure is worked up, and in proper condition to be laid before the Committees, and I firmly believe if a couple of us will go there we can have it passed before the 4th of March, and mark my word, or no measure will stand a ghost of a chance.  I am glad you are East if you can carry your state for the bill  I will carry this state, but of this not one word. {6 words underline]   I am afraid I have not been able to clearly present my views, which in the space of letter is almost impossible, but sufficient to, I hope induce you to throw every other measure aside & stick to your original one, the Springer bill.  If you go on to Washington, I wish you would come via Buffalo and come up here and see me, an hours talk would be far better than a weeks writing.  Read carefully the enclosed and see if I have not covered the entire ground.

                                        Very Truly Yours
                                               M H Penrose
                                                   Bvt Brig Genl
                                                        U.S.A.

P. S.   Suppose we quietly get up a Committe to consist of Genl Ayer of the Arty. yourself of the Cav. and myself of the Inf. with Maj Egbert of the 12th as sect and Treasurer, and ask the Army to back us on the Springer-Harmer measures, let me know how this view [?} strikes you.  Egbert is a first rate lawyer.     No time to lose.

know yourselves what you want? [5 words underline] and surely it looked so.  I found also they would not be bothered with statistics.  Cautiously I presented my address, to first one then another, and I found it "took", [underline] as one said to me "Genl this is the first Bill or measure that has been presented to us in a tangeable form".  My time was too short to follow up a most opportune moment to  press the passage of this measure, which I am quite confident could have been done, could I have remained and could have offered the money.  Most reluctantly did I give it up for that Session, but determined to again bring it up this Session, complete with a modified Harmer bill.  My object was two fold, the Springer bill [strike] and the [strike] Harmer  bills had received the approval of over 80 percent of the Officers of the Army, and were both before the Military Committees of Congress, it would therefore not [underline] be new [underline] business, and could therefore be included early in the Session, a most important point, and secondly, these bills were favorably [underline] considered by members, another most important point.  Now why should we try to

to introduce new measures, when those already in are what the officers, by their approval, state, contain what they want?  do we not threw ourselves open to the conclusion, as has already been remarked, "that we dont know ourselves wheat we want?" most truly, yes!  Again, Your last bill would retire myself & several others as Lieut Colonels, while you & all Cols. would be retired as Brig Genls.  Do you think this is just to us in view of our war services?  I dont wish to be arrogant but there is no officer of the army today on the list who can show a better record then myself, and it is only necessary to turn to the reports to show this.  I was not as fortunate as some of my contemporaries who had strong political influence in procuring higher grade in the Regular Army though most positively promised it when i left Wash, in 1865.  The Springer bill does not discriminate, your last one does. [5 words underline]  And will meet with the strongest kind of opposition from many officers, who like myself believe that no bill should pass that discriminates. Fort Sully Dak
Jan 24th 1888
Gen'l B. H. Grierson U. S. A.
My dear General

          Yours of the 15th inst has reached me at last, our R. R. have been blocked and we have had but three mails since the 8th inst. & hope they will now open and that this will reach you in a reasonable length of time.
    You may rest assured I will do all in my power to aid in the passage of the bill proposed, but I would be as much surprised at it, as if some one would give me a million a minute for twenty four hours, it is too old a "chestnut", however, there is nothing like trying.  I am more doubtful of its passage, in the shape of a seperate measure.  I believe the only way it can be accomplished is to get some member in each of the Committees to put it on the general Army bill, in one of the sections under "Provided &c", and that it should

[in pencil right hand corner] W. H. Penrose  397    1-24-88 203
not be broached eaven in Committe until just before the bill is ready to go to the House on its finial passage. You may rest assured, those on the retired list who are retired with a less rank, will kill your measure unless they are included, and if they are, I do not believe it can be passed.  There must be no time for discussion, it must be sprung [underline] at the last moment [underline 2 words], as the bill for the increase of rank in the A. G. Dept. was last Session.  I know one member on the House Committee and will sound him on the subject at once, I am inclined to believe there will be no military legislation of any moment this session, both parties are standing on the defencive, and will do nothing that will in any way increase expenditures. If brivet [underline] rank of General in the Volunteers is not contemplated, there are but few of us the bill would effect, as I figure it there are 5 in the Cavalry, 2 in the Artillery and 8 in the Infantry, and class legislation would I am afraid be brought up against it.  Again if you wont fight you cant win a victory.

                                                                                      Yours Truly
                                                                                       Wm. H. Penrose
                                                                                              U. S. A.

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF THE MISSOURI
Fort Leavenworth, Kas.   July 15  1870.
Genl. B. H. Grierson
Comdg Ft Sill I. T.
General

                       Your two letters of the 5th inst have just been received.  Your action in relation to the petition of the Kiowas & Comanches to return to their reservation is cordially approved.
    The order prohibiting Indians from entering Military Posts in this Dept., bore reference only to the tribes with which we have been and are likely again to be at war.  In

((unclear)) district of country to the Iowas and Comanches, and Apaches, ((Cheyennes?)) and Arapahoes, they affiliated tribes and the ((unclear)) and other Indians who have been always at peace are not intended to be embraced in the order.  It is always bad policy to permit Indians

with whom our relations are  equivocal, sometimes at peace and sometimes at war, to come within the building or quarters of  Military post not so much on account of ((unclear)) pure treachery or malice, as because it establishes relations of intimacy with enlisted men, employees or citizens which may at any time occasion disputes and quarrels between individual Indians and ((unclear)) persons, which at times lend to serious difficulties with a whole Indian tribe.  It is not ((unclear)) this risk by permitting Indians to loaf at will about the Sutter Store or other public places of a military post.  It is far better to have some fixed place for the Indians to stay just outside the post and as far as practicable to prohibit intercourse with them by any one not having special permit from the Post Commander.  I wish you to impress this rule within the limits of the Military ((unclear ))around your post.  You will find that its

strict enforcement will solve many petty quarrels and  disturbances which oftentimes lead to widespread difficulties.  ((unclear several words))...  impress.this view upon the Indian Agents. The less intercourse there is between Indians in so ((difficult? )) a relation as those near F Sill with ((unclear )) white men whether soldiers or civilians, the better both for the Indian and the white man,until the Indian becomes more civilized and the white man more under the dominion of law.
I am General respectfully

Fort Gibson
January 5 1869
Dear General
I received General Sherman's communication about two hours before the courier starts today, the mails have been delayed near to 10 days, so uncertain as to whether General Sheridan and yourself were en route to this point and the courier might not reach you.  I opened it and took a copy to retain.
We had had no Arbuckle mail in two weeks and our last mail for Arbuckle and Cobb sent 10 days ago was returned and sent out again yesterday.  We have no late news papers, and no late news. The

enclosed are all the private letters that have not been forwarded.  Trains have been coming in rapidly the last two weeks, and I should think there are supplies enough for any emergency.  Our companies here are being rapidly reduced by discharge and at the end of the month we will be unable to furnish any extra duty men.  Numerous communications await the action of Regtl Commander 10th Cavalry but of not special importance so I have retained them on file.  
All the officers and ladies are well with kind regards to Capt. Alvord, Maj Woodward and yourself.
Very Truly 
R. Rees
2nd Lt. 6th ((a.a.a.g.?))

Head Quarters Dist. Indian Territory
Fort Gibson, C.N. January 8 1869
Dear General, We have courier from Fort Cobb and Capt. Leefe in today.  They report Col Rockwell's trains delayed by  high water so the supt. Mr. Buck with mechanics leaves in the morning to build rafts or boats to cross them.  I despatched courier from here, who Capt Leefe reports waiting to cross a stream that he has just passed so I send copy of the despatches by this courier in case the other doesn't reach you. 
I also send all the late papers we have, and they are 2 weeks old.  The Fort Scott mail is very irregular, and will be so for some time.
Regards to all
Very Truly 
R Rees
2nd Lt. 6th Inf. ((a.a.a.g?))

Sub Agency, Wichita, Ks
Washita River 7th mo. 9th 1870.
General Grierson,
Dear friend:
I have a communication from Agent Tatum, dated the 7th inst. in relation to the employment of the Indians on the Washita, by thee, to go as guides in pursuit of those Indians who are in open hostilities against the govt. - This is the first official notice I have received that their services were desired:  I have pretty fully set forth the reasons for the course I have pursued in this matter in a letter to Agent Tatum, even date, but I would now add that, fearing the Indians of the Washita would be drawn into the war, from an expression of fear on their part, of leaving their villages for the purpose of obtaining supplies, thus exposing their families and homes to attacks from the war Indians.  I "couciled" them to keep as much as possible about their own villages and not to leave them unnecessarily.  I told them I was opposed to all war + fighting, that I could not, under any circumstances, kill a man

myself, and that I could not encourage any one else to do it. - That I respected the feelings and views of those who differed from me - those who had been educated under different circumstances and schooled in the Indian country.  But still I was one who thought all wars and fighting wrong and a large body of those who were their friends and were laboring for their good thought as I did.  Therefore I would advise them to do all they could in a peaceable manner to stop the depredations of bad Indians, but I hoped they would not be drawn into a war with them. - Some days after this I was called upon by the Caddo Chiefs and they informed me that they had been to Fort Sill, upon a request from thee:  That thy object in sending for them was, to engage their services in pursuit of the hostile Indians; but they had objected to it, and gave their reasons for doing so.  They said that one of the principal reasons was, that the Govt. had not fulfilled their promise on former occasions when they had been similarly engaged:  And they also remembered what I had told them a few days before.
Now, any arrangement thou thinks it necessary to make with these Indians I shall not interfere with as much as I should regret their being drawn

into the war, for the reasons I have given.  Indeed I have no right to interfere with any arrangement thou and the indians may agree upon.
With great respect I am thy frd,
Jon.a. Richards.

I have just received the order making Medicine Bluff your Hd Quarters -  I know that you do not desire this, but I am personally glad to have you nearer us - Col. Fort Arbuckle C.N.
March 5. 1869
Dear General,
Lt. Nordstrom arrived here yesterday and informed me of the condition of affairs at Medicine Creek.  It is a shame that the troops were left as he represents - I immediately dispatched two wagons with 4000 lbs flour.  They should arrive on Monday - I have sent Huntley's train after forage.  As soon as it returns I will share it with you should I not hear in the mean time that Shirley has arrive with the corn for which he has contracted,but which I fear he will not

deliver - Jocelyn with his company left yesterday - his company as well as Robinson's are rationed to the last of this month - nothing news
Very respectfully and truly
James P. Roy
Maj: 6 Infty
((unclear)) Maj. Gen. B.H. Grierson
Comdg ((unclear))
Medicine Bluff
Ind. Ty.

Dear General, Your favor was duly received - I appreciate fully the sad condition of the cavalry mount, and I immediately dispatched one wagon with all the forage at this post consisting of ((26?)) sacks of corn - I am in hopes that Huntley will get here by Friday.  As soon as he arrives I will forward every grin I can properly spare.  We have had a heavy rain here lasting twenty four hours which will set us back some.  this want of forge is entirely due to she short-sightedness of whoever made the contract for corn with an irresponsible party like Shirley, who has now four thousand bushels to deliver on a contract which should have terminated on the 31st January

But there is no use crying over spilt milk so we shall have to do the best we can now If you can only get your animals through the next two weeks, I think all will be well, and I shall be able to supply you at least in part - Carland and myself are both doing everything to help you - I am much obliged for your order allowing Carland to remain with me at present.  His services cannot be dispensed with here without serious detriment to the public service - I sent you Blaine's substitute which passed the House on the 19th February by a large majority, attached to the army appropriations bill,

No news. I conveyed your ((regards?)) to the ladies of the 10th Cavalry -
Your very truly
James P. Roy

Sir:
I have the honor to inform you that Kicking Bird arrived at the Agency yesterday with thirty eight mules and one horse which he delivered to Mr. Tatum, the Agent.  The latter accepted them as a full return (in connection with the two mules previously brought in ) of the forty one mules stolen by ((Sotunta?)) and other Indians from Mr. Warren's train.  Mr. Tatum and myself had a "talk" with Kicking Bird and ((Pacer?)) in which we expressed our gratification at this conduct in bringing in these mules.  Mr. Tatum told them he should treat Kicking Bird and Pacer as the principal chiefs of the Kiowas and Apaches and that they must nominate other chiefs in place of

Eagle Heart, Big Bow and Fast Bear and that he would appoint and recognize the ones they should nominate as chiefs.  Kicking Bird made many good promises for himself and the tribe.  He said they would never more raid on the whites; that they wanted to follow the road traveled by the Caddos, that their hearts were good and they wanted to forget all the bad things done and said and wanted the agent and the officers to forget them.  He then asked for assistance from the government, and wanted the agent and the Commanding Officer of Fort Still to intercede for the release of Sotantu.  He promised simply to write to Washington stating that he had returned the mules; that his people had come back to their reservation and to repeat the "talks" we had had.  He says the Kiowas have come in "two moves", and are encamped on a branch of the North Fork of Red River and thinks it is what we call Buffalo creek.  Is some

it is further East than Sweet Water.  Says when he returns they are going to cross to the Washita above Fort Cobb.  Pacer reports the Apaches as on the Washita
Mr. Tatum recommences the issue of rations to the Kiowas and Apaches to day.
The two absent bands of Comanches are reported as still off the reservation, none of them being with, or near the Kiowas.  Mr. Jones, who starts tomorrow to join you, will give you further particulars.
Very Respectfully
Your obt. servt.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of Aug. 19th inst. by the hands of Kicking Bird, who came in on the 28th with chiefs from most of the Kiowa bands. not ask whether or not they were branded U.S.  Two of the mules were white, and the horse was an iron grey. Some of the Indians with Kicking Bird told the men at the log camp that ((Moowis?)) band,or some other Indians from "The West" had recently stolen some Cavalry horses from Fort Griffin.  I can learn nothing definite in regard to this report.  the Kiowas are on the Washita, as reported by Kicking Bird. Fort Still, I.T.
April 2nd 1872
Colonel B.H. Grierson
10th U.S. Cavalry
Sir:  I have the honor to state that I find it almost impossible to fully comply with your request in regard to a report on the relative merits of the several companies of the regiment stationed at the post for the following reasons.
First: While one may be best as regards the condition of arms and accoutrements, another may be as to the care and condition of horses; another as to the condition of quarters, kitchen, mess hall and out houses; another as to the disciple and soldierly bearing of its enlisted men; another as to knowledge of duties, tactics, drill and general instruction; another as to the management and care exercised in the matters of books, papers, etc; another in the  management of supplies, rations and their cooking,

the company fund and purchases therewith etc. etc. and several of the companies may be equally good in a number of these particulars.
Second.  the real efficiency of a company in the field depends so much upon the character of its commander; upon his judgment and coolness, and his power of controlling men and commanding their respect and confidence, that the company seemingly most meritorious while in garrison might be the least valuable on an active campaign.  Understanding, however, that you desire an opinion as to the relative merits of the companies in garrison judged as an Inspector would judge them by the condition and appearance of arms, accoutrements, clothing, equipments, barracks, mess halls, kitchens, outhouse and stables, and by the appearance and bearing of the men, I will classify the ten companies by this standard.

I would place "H." "M" and "B" together , "G." "A." "K" and (( "C"?)) together, and "I,""L" and "D"together in each case in the order named.
It is my opinion, however, that if "A" was occupying regularly built quarters, and if "G" had independent quarters, kitchen and mess hall, they would be equal to the best in every particular.
In some respects (("C"?)) would pass a better inspection than "K" and fully as good as "G", and a close criticism would place "B" lower in the list, and perhaps "D" higher up.
Without reference to efficiency in the field the above is a fair clasification as judged by me after several critical inspections.
I am, sir
Very Respectfully
Your obt. servt.
G.W. Schofield
Maj 10th Cavly.

Please write me and tell me how the ((Iowa?)) Rail roads in that ((unclear)) have progressed, and what are the prospects.  I can hardly come this year.  That will

do so at some future time - and always feel great interest in that quarter of our Dominions - Yesterday the Comm. of Indian Affair came here to see about allowing Satanta to come to Washington.  Genl ((unclear)) and I both thought it bad policy to allow a Prisoner convicted of murder to come to Washington, and we all agreed to see the President this morning - we have been there and the President instructed the Acting Sec of Interior Genl ((unclear)) to refuse the Coming here of Satanta

and Big Tree - If I ever come to Fort Sill, and any of those Indians come about bragging of killing people in Texas, I wont bother their courts, but have the grave dug at once.  It does seem to me these Indian loving christians have abundant faith, for I hear of more indian murders now than ever before - How far up from Galveston toward Dallas is the Texas Road finished - when and where will the two Roads likely meet?  Was anything ever done towards straightening

and improving the Road from Gibson to Sill?  Did McKenzie every find a good point for a direct Road for Fort Griffin to Sill? and did he find any good country, water and grass up ((abut?)) the ((Double?)) Mountain? 
My best regards to Mrs G and children.
Your friend, ((P.H.?)) Sherman
General

Headquarters Army of the United States.
Washington D.C.Nov -29 1872
Dear Grierson,
Yours of 23 is received and I assure you of my  continued friendship and esteem.  I almost fear the next vacancy that will call for the promotion of a Colonel.  Neither mine or Sheridan's death will make a vacancy - the as now 3 Maj Generals and 77 Brigadiers - Cooke can be retired having reached the age of 62 and over but this will

not make a vacancy for there remain six other Brigadiers, none of whom will probably retire, so that death alone will produce a necessity for promotion.  Should this occur in General Grants term I ((unclear)) he will let the seniority rule prevail, because of the controversy kicked up by selection in time of Peace.  In war he would not hesitate to select the one he considered the best.
No arrangements are yet made for the Inauguration next March - I don't

suppose it will be any thing but the usual civic procession and Ball - If I can make any decent excuse for asking you here I will do so  with pleasure, but you must know that the ((unclear)) of War and Presidents oppose any thing of the sort for the Politicians are most jealous of the Military. and seem actually to hate the sight of the uniforms.  So much so that I have half a mind to advise such as happen to be here to wear civil dress.  I am sorry to hear you are unwell

Anything in the nature of a loan you surely can have by asking.  But that probably would not suit your purpose.  When you look to the condition of things in Arizona, Idaho, and the Upper Missouri you can imagine the number of applications I daily receive for special favors - Present me kindly to Mrs. Grierson and the family
sincerely your Friend
W.T.Sherman
General

Washington D.C. Feb 20 1873
Dear Grierson,
Your letter of Feb 14 was duly received, and I am glad you like the station assigned you.  It will give you a good rest after the confusion  of an Indian ((Life?)).  If you come to Washington it will be very grand to see you.  There will be a great crowd.  Mostly of Citizens and Militia - our battalion of Regulars and our battery of artillery will be here

and the Corps of Cadets will  complete the Escort so far as the Regular Army is concerned - I understand the Marines and Cadets of the Naval School will come and a great variety of Militia.  Personally I will not take part save to appear in the Senate Chamber and go out on the East Portico when the oath is administered.  the display will be mostly Civic, under Civic Marshals,  and ((As'd?)).  There will be a Grand Ball, but this also

will be mostly patronized by Strangers, as the ladies of Washington are pretty well used up by the Regular operations of the Season.
I hardly expect to come to St. Louis this Spring but I surely will come at some period of your detail, but I have so many personal friends there I will be  compelled to stay in town.
My best regards to Mrs. Grierson and the boys.
Your Sincere Friend
W.T.Sherman
General

Headquarters Army of the United States
Washington, D.C. Jan 4 1881
Genl B.H. Grierson
Fort Concho, Texas,
Dear Grierson,
I have your kind letter of Dec 26, and think you are entitled to an answer - The law makes no provision for the retirement of the General, or Lieutenant General; and one death ((unclear)) will give no vacany or promotion I am in splendid physical health and probably more ((unclear))

occupied than if living in my own house  at Ft. Lewis with such occupation as I could command there.  There has been of late a good deal of gossip and feeling about the forcible retirement of Genl ((unclear)) to make room for ((Miles?)) and having ((unclear)) McDowell older in year and senior - rich- and when retirement would give his officers a lift: but the rumor of my retirement did not grow out of this at all, but a former Case. Maj Genl Schofield at West Point was dreadfully

exercised because the President seemed to take ground against him in the Whitaker Case.  He demanded to be retired and to be assigned to a command  equal in approximation to his Rank - at that time (November) we had ((here?))three Divisions, and I did not want to create another, and advised Schofield to be easy - to worry
along till 1882.  when I would be 62 rs old, and might ((unclear)) a roving commission - not Retire in a legal sense - Call Sheridan to Washington, and give ((unclear)) Schofield that

Division.  Out of this grew the rumor that I contemplated retirement. but the Whitaker matter would not stay down; and the President cut the Gordian Knot by relieving Schofield by Howard and giving the former a Division of the Gulf - cut out of the former Division of the Atlantic and Missouri - that release me of all pressure and I stand perfectly uncommitted and will act as time advances just as I think right and proper - 
As always your friend
W.T. Sherman

Ft. Sill I. T.
March 9th 1874.
Dear General.

                        You will pardon me for bothering you, but as we are all looking for a consolidation I want to ask that you will use your influence in my behalf, should this Regiment be amongst the unfortunate ones.  I would like to get into one where I would make by it in the way Rank, dont misunderstand me that I am tired of this Regiment for I am not, and I am quite certain that I am one of its best friends, but if we are to be consolidated every few years, I should to gain as much by it as possible and I hope you will same me from being mustered out as I am certain I would starve out of the

army.  I rank all the Lieutenants in the arm [strike] 9th Cavalry also the 8th and most of them the other Regiments.

                         Genl. Davidson leaves here tomorrow with three Companies B. C. and M. for the field, for the purpose of establishing a line of Post during the summer for to try and keep the Indians out of Texas.  K. is down at Camp Augur (a supply camp that has been established about 49 miles from this Post on Red River, near the mouth of China Tree Creek.  I would be there, but I am on duty at the Post as A. C. S. and it is to be seen what kind of a one I will make.
                        I should like very much to go out, as I dont like to be confined in Garrison all the time, and it is expected that Lone Wolf will make a break for Texas soon, as he lost his

son a short time ago in Texas.

                  Nothing new here.  Every thing seems to be quiet and peaceable.
                  Mrs. S. sends her kindest regards to yourself and Mrs. Grierson, as also do I.
                                       Yours Truly &c.
                                       Robt. G. Smither
                                       1st Lt 10" Cavalry.

To Genl. B. H. Grierson
U.S. Army,
P. S.
We have the finest boy in the U.S. without exception.

                                                      R. G. S.

Ft. Sill I. T.
August 31st 74.
Dear General,

                         Your kind and most welcome letter was duly received, and accept my many thanks for kindness in sending Mrs Smither passes.  I have only heard from her once and that was when she reached the Rail Road, she received and them and wished me to write you and send her sincere thanks.
       I suppose you have heard of the little brush had at the Witchita Agency, with the Indians and the result of it.  I know very little about it, as I was not there, and you will find the particulars in the New York Herald, of about August 29th before or after.  We have had no rain here

for more than two months and no prospects for any, everyone of the little streams in the County are becoming dried up.

         Genl. Augur arrived here last evening, his son and Capt Comly of the Ordnance came with him.  Genl. Baird is also here, there is now 9 Companies of the Regiment here or temporarily attached to this Post.
         Genl. Davidson's little Boy or rather Eldest boy Willie, shot himself accidentally with a shot gun, he has a very severe wound and one that I am afraid will trouble him all his life time.
         Genl. please send the amount you paid for telegrams and I will return it to you as soon as I receive your letter,  I hope the time may come when I will have the oportunity of returning your favors.

and I assure you I appreciate them.

    I have been very busy indeed of late trying to get subsistence stores for the commands that are to be supplied from this Post, and I am trying to go out with the troops that go in the field.
         Kindest rememberances to Mrs Grierson and the family, with much respect I remain
                 Yours truly &c
                       Robt. G. Smither
                       1 Lt 10th Cavly

Fort Concho Tex.
9. P. M.  March, 20, 79.
Dear General,

                             I just received a telegram which is of interest to you, and which I think you should have.  I assure you I am sorry to see you leave the Regiment as it will be for some months before this court business is over.
                                     Smither, Adjt

P. S. Congress has met and organized, and rumors that

Army bill will pass, I would send yo some papers but it is after taps.  I have sent down to Mrs Grierson to see if she has anything to send out to you.

    Lieut Orleman has been attacked with congestion of the brain, and one side of his person is paralized.
